channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report I-2024100030
item.description:
Report I-2024100030

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-30T00:33:00+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-12
  • City: ONTARIO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Individual not a company
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 1900000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During the filling of the trailer, an end plug thermal pressure relief device (TPRD) had an unplanned activation. The TPRD vent manifold intended to safely route any venting gas appeared to be improperly assembled allowing high pressure hydrogen gas to escape through leaks in the vent manifold. The resulting leaks created ignited the hydrogen causing significant damage to the trailer and damage to the another trailer being filled along side the trailer that caught fire.

item.description:

  • City: OREM

  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE UPS FACILITY IN OREM, UTAH, AN AIR PACKAGE WAS INSPECTED DUE TO THERMAL TRACKING LABEL BEING PARTIALLY TORN AND ILLEGIBLE WITH SIGNS OF PREVIOUS MARKS REMOVED. PACKAGE OPENED TO FIND NINE IPADS IN OTTER BOXES WITH CHARGING CORDS. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THERE IS A RED FRAGILE STICKER APPLIED. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XCH experienced a UN1823 Caustic Soda release from (2) 55-pound paper bags. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1 cup of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the trailer floor from two bags damaged by a forklift blade. The two bags, and all released product were collected into a 55-gallon poly drum. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage

item.title: Report E-2024030577
item.description:
Report E-2024030577

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-29T18:14:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-26
  • City: SPARKS
  • State: NV
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal URE experienced a UN1830 Sulfuric Acid ACS release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of product released to a 23’ x 10’ area of the wooden/metal trailer floor and walls along with a 35’ x 10’ area of the asphalt lot below the trailer. The release was caused due to a forklift puncture. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one for shipment on. Absorbents & sodium bicarb were deployed and worked into the impacted areas to clean and neutralize the release. The impacted absorbents were collected into (11) 55-gallon poly drums. The damaged tote was cut up and containerized along with the impacted pallets into 4 supersacks. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage

  • Description: SequenceEvent: loadside manager called out a damaged hazmat. HESS specialist responded and brought it back in a lined tote. upon inspection of the contents, HESS specialist found that all the bottles had been packed into the box upside down. HESS specialist reoriented them right side up and placed the tote on the drain mats in the incoming damaged hazmat/LQ area. DescribePack: one bottle leaked due to loose cap and all bottles being packed upside down in box. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: placed in lined tote, moved to drain mats. bottles reoriented right side up.

item.title: Report X-2024031363
item.description:
Report X-2024031363

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-29T18:14:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-25
  • City: SANTA MARIA
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: UNLOAD MANAGER CAME TO QA AT ABOUT 5AM AND INFORMED QA THERE WAS A HAZMAT DAMAGE AT ONE OF THE UNLOAD BAY DOORS. QA IMMEDIATELY WENT OVER THERE AND INSPECTED THE AREA AND LUCKILY THERE WASNT ANY AFFECTED SURFACE AREAS IN THE TRAILER, HOWEVER, FIVE BOXES WERE SPILLED ON. THE UNLOAD MANAGER PUT THE DAMAGED HAZMAT INTO A HAZBAG AND QA PUT IT INTO A LINED BIN AND IT WAS BROUGHT OVER TO THE QA TABLE FOR PROCESSING. DescribePack: AT FIRST GLANCE THERE WAS A WET SPOT ON THE SIDE OF THE BOX BUT NO OTHER SIGNS OF DAMAGE. WHEN QA OPENED THE PACKAGE THERE WAS A 2.5 GALLON PLASTIC BOTTLE OF CONCENTRATED LIQUID DISHMACHINE DETERGENT THAT HAD A LOOSE CAP AND HAD SPILLED ONTO THE SLOTTED PARTITION THAT WAS USED TO BRACE IT. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: THE DAMAGED HAZMAT WAS QUICKLY PUT INTO A HAZBAG AND THEN PUT INTO A LINED BIN. THE SPILLED ON PACKAGES WERE REMOVED AND PUT ON THE SPILL TRAY AND COLLECTED AFTER THE HAZMAT WAS SAFELY MOVED TO THE QA TABLE.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-29T18:14:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-22
  • City: FLINT
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Hepaco was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 40ft-by-2ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that five (5) gallons of material was released due to a load shift that resulted in one (1) 55-gallon metal drum becoming punctured. Hepaco personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area then wiped it down with a Simple Green. The spent material and the damaged 55- gallon metal drum was overpacked into one (1) 85-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.description:

  • City: NEWARK
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Metal drum was at the rear terminus of moving NC belt, the weight of the oncoming packages forced a protruding metal rod from another package to impact the drum, puncturing it and forcing it over the side of the belt onto the floor below. Punctured drum was placed in a hazmat bag lined tote, spreading spill on floor was contained using absorbent tubing, spilled material was squeegied into containment zone and mopped up using absorbent pads. DescribePack: Metal drum was punctured on the side about an inch or beneath the top lid of the drum. The puncture runs about an inch in length, between an 8th and a 1/4 inch in width. In addition, wet label and denting on other side of drum suggestive of a very small crack, likely the result of the impact with the floor. DurationRel: 0 and MitigateEffect: Area was evacuated, Punctured drum was placed in a hazmat bag lined tote, spreading spill on floor was contained using absorbant tubing, spilled material was squeegied into containment zone and mopped up using absorbant pads. Fans used to disperse fumes.

item.title: Report X-2024031367
item.description:
Report X-2024031367

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-29T18:14:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-21
  • City: SANTA MARIA
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: UNLOAD MANAGER CAME TO QA AT ABOUT 5AM AND INFORMED QA THERE WAS A HAZMAT DAMAGE AT ONE OF THE UNLOAD BAY DOORS. QA IMMEDIATELY WENT OVER THERE AND INSPECTED THE AREA AND LUCKILY THERE WASNT ANY AFFECTED SURFACE AREAS IN THE TRAILER, HOWEVER, FIVE BOXES WERE SPILLED ON. THE UNLOAD MANAGER PUT THE DAMAGED HAZMAT INTO A HAZBAG AND QA PUT IT INTO A LINED BIN AND IT WAS BROUGHT OVER TO THE QA TABLE FOR PROCESSING. DescribePack: AT FIRST GLANCE THERE WAS A WET SPOT ON THE SIDE OF THE BOX BUT NO OTHER SIGNS OF DAMAGE. WHEN QA OPENED THE PACKAGE THERE WAS A 2.5 GALLON PLASTIC BOTTLE OF CONCENTRATED LIQUID DISHMACHINE DETERGENT THAT HAD A LOOSE CAP AND HAD SPILLED ONTO THE SLOTTED PARTITION THAT WAS USED TO BRACE IT. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: THE DAMAGED HAZMAT WAS QUICKLY PUT INTO A HAZBAG AND THEN PUT INTO A LINED BIN. THE SPILLED ON PACKAGES WERE REMOVED AND PUT ON THE SPILL TRAY AND COLLECTED AFTER THE HAZMAT WAS SAFELY MOVED TO THE QA TABLE.

DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Tip package upright, liquid was leaking out of top.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: At 7:20pm, during outbound a van line manager reported to QA that van on WA 335 had strong odor. While walking to the van, I noticed a leaking hazmat on the tugger cart next to the IC rollers on vanline 3. This hazmat was wet on the bottom and top corners and was placed next to other hazmats from the same shipper by package handler. I placed hazmat in plastic bag/red tote and took it to QA1. I also inspected van and tugger cart for spills which I could not find. Finally, I informed van line managers of what I discovered. DescribePack: The large main cap leaked because it is loose. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The hazmat was placed in a plastic bag and bin.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: During our inbound sort, a hazmat package was being unloaded from a van when it was dropped. This caused a bend in one of the bottles in the package but also the cap on another bottle came off and the contents of the bottle leaked out of its container. The package was gathered to a safe space and the spillage was contained. DescribePack: The cap on the bottle came off causing the bottle to leak its contents. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Kitty litter was placed on the floor where the spillage took place and safety precautions were maintained alerting employees passing by.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package handler was not following proper handling of hazardous materials. Package handler attempted to lift the metal pail over his head to place onto the van line when he dropped the pail. As a result, the pail dented causing a puncher hole where liquid was leaking from. Ops Manager on the van line immediately contacted the quality assurance team and the spill was quickly contained. DescribePack: Metal pail has a dent on the side with a small puncher hole. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The metal pail was quickly placed in a hazmat bag with loose absorb material and placed in a hazardous spill drum and kept in the hazmat cage.

item.title: Report X-2024031227
item.description:
Report X-2024031227

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-29T18:14:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-20
  • City: LONDONDERRY
  • State: NH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package handler removed package from belt and found the package to be leaking a white powder. Package handler put item in red hazmat bucket and delivered to QA area. I found the package and began inspecting it immediately. It was quickly discovered the package was leaking white powder from the bottom seam of the pail. The loose powder was cleaned up and put in the hazmat bucket that the pail was contained in. Immediately took box and pail to the Hazmat cage area. DescribePack: The bottom of the pail was found to have a crack along the seam, it is estimated the crack goes around the outer circumference of the pail about half way. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: Immediate removal of the container, red hazmat bucket and outer box. These items were moved to the Hazmat cage. The spilled/leaked out white powder substance was cleaned out of the pallet and off of the floor immediately and dumped into the red hazmat bin that the pail is contained in.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was brought to QA due to it leaking when being loaded to a van. 1 of 4 items inside had a loose cap causing the spillage to leak onto the other 3 items and to eat through the box itself. Liquid was cleaned up in the area using absorbent pads and dry dirt. Actual package was placed inside a plastic bag then placed inside hazardous drum. DescribePack: Package cap was not on item properly and no seal was on item to separate the liquid portion from the cap. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Cap was tightened and entire package placed in hazardous drum.

  • City: VICTORIA
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package handler was inbound scanning trailer 571968 when she found the leaking hazmat 4 walls into the 53ft trailer. Upon discovery she informed management which called for a damaged hazmat over the radio. QA arrived and placed the leaking package into a hazardous materials only tote and removed it from the unload to the hazmat cage for further inspection. Upon inspection it was found that 1 of the gallon glass jugs had shattered in shipping causing the box to be completely saturated. DescribePack: 1 gallon glass jug completely shattered due to inadequate bracing inside of the package. The only bracing protection was cardboard slotted partitions above and below the glass jugs. Hazmat package was incorrectly loaded into trailer, being located 4 walls into it. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Hazmat was placed into a hazardous materials only tote and removed from unload to prevent further leakage.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-18
  • City: VICKSBURG
  • State: MS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Circle K
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 8500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: It was reported that approximately 150-gallons of gasoline were released impacting concrete and nearby soil. The spill occurred when the driver opened the drop head on his tanker trailer and accidentally overfilled it, causing approximately 150-gallons of gasoline to spill out. The driver deployed boom while waiting for assistance. The police and the fire department were notified and in route. The Fire Department responded and put down absorbents. The state of Mississippi was notified of the incident, but no report number could be provided by Catherine Bell. E3 Environmental arrived on site and swept-in absorbents solidifying released material on the impacted concrete. E3 Environmental scraped the surface of the impacted soil area and sprayed with microblaze. the impacted absorbents and soil were containerized into one (1) 55-gallon metal drum.

DescribePack: DUE TO THE NATURE OF THE ITEM/SPILL, IT WAS NOT CLEAR AS TO THE EXACT INNER PACKAGE FAILURE. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: RED TOTES PRE-LINED WITH HAZMAT BAGS WERE USED TO PLACE IMPACTED BOXES INTO, WHICH STEMMED THE LEAKAGE AND REDUCED ADDITIONAL VAPOR DISPERSION. IN ADDITION, CHEMICAL NEUTRALIZER WAS APPLIED TO THE SPILL.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was found in trailer during the unloading process. Package was discovered already damaged and leaking. Package was placed in a lined hazmat tote and taken to the damaged hazmat cage, where it was repackaged into a damaged hazmat salvage drum. DescribePack: External packaging (cardboard box) was stained and wet. Inspection shows a plastic bag suspended by carboard liners on all sides. Plastic bag had leaked from tied point. Bag contained a metal can which had been taped shut but had leaked from the lid. Contents of metal can is an absorbent and a glass 1QT bottle of Nitric Acid 70% which had broken, leaking all contents into absorbent and external packaging. DurationRel: 4 and MitigateEffect: Package was immediately removed from service flow and placed inside damaged hazmat cage. Internal packaging and absorbent prevented external release other than the box being visibly discolored and moist.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was found leaking white granules on the IC belt near belt 4. The belt was stopped and the package was transfered to a hazmat bag lined hazmat tote, and the ic belt was cleaned with latex gloves and a dust pan. Upon inspection the plastic drum had cracked along the side and leaked around 5lbs of the calcium hypochlorite granules. DescribePack: The drum cracked along the side at around 7 inches. the crack was thin and in a straight line from the top to middle area of the drum. DurationRel: 0 and MitigateEffect: The release was mitigated by the IC belt being stopped and the hazmat being contained in a hazmat bag to catch any further leakage.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Shortly after pushback of American Airlines Flight 199 from the gate, passenger in seat 27L had a powerbank that began to overheat. The crew put the battery in the fire containment bag as a precaution and returned to the gate to remove the battery from the aircraft. The Captain dropped the powerbank out the Flight Deck window to the Ramp. No injuries or damages were reported by the crew. After the battery was removed the aircraft taxied out and departed MXP without further issue. Captain Sorenson wishes to extend thanks to MXP personnel for quick and efficient coordination in handling the Incident.

  • Description: It was reported that approximately 1 cup of Starlite Built Liquid Alkali was released from (1) 55-gallon DF due to the cap coming off of the drum. Hepaco arrived on site and neutralized the impacted area on top of the impacted drum. Once cleaned and neutralized, Hepaco replaced the damaged cap with a new one and ensured it was on tight. All 4 drums were then resecured and shrink-wrapped. One 30-gallon DF of waste was generated containing impacted absorbent pads and PPE.

item.title: Report E-2024030494
item.description:
Report E-2024030494

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-28T15:13:06+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-15
  • City: JERSEY CITY
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: First Call Environmental was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted an 8ft-by-3ft area of the asphalt lot and two (2) areas of the trailer floor measuring 8ft-by-15ft and 8ft-by-4ft and estimated that twenty-five (25) gallons of material was released due to forklift damaging one (1) 275-gallon poly tote. First Call Environmental personnel neutralized the impacted areas and the impacted wooden pallet and used absorbents to collect the material. The wooded pallet was broken down and placed into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The impacted absorbents were recovered and containerized into two (2) 55- gallon poly drums. The remaining product in the damaged poly tote was transferred to a new tote and the damaged tote was cut up and placed into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024030519
item.description:
Report E-2024030519

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-28T15:13:06+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-12
  • City: BASTROP
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: OCCIDENTAL CHEMICAL CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At approximately 8:30 am, a OxyChem truck driver was delivering Caustic Soda to a customer site (Morehouse BioEnergy) located in Bastrop, LA. The driver met with the customer site operator, completed the “In the Interest of Safety Form” (which is a form utilized by OxyChem truck drivers to ensure that enough space exists in a customer tank prior to unloading), hooked up offloading hoses, and began offloading. Near the end of the offloading process, product began to overflow from the customer's storage tank into the containment area. The OxyChem truck driver immediately shut down the offloading process. The customer site operator was present with the driver when the overflow occurred and made a comment that they would have to check the tank level indicator for accuracy because the calculation during the completion of the “In the Interest of Safety Form” showed that there was sufficient capacity available within the storage tank. Customer site personnel washed down the area. The spill was estimated to be approximately 75-gallons. No injuries, property damage, or environmental impact as a result of the incident.

item.title: Report E-2024020355
item.description:
Report E-2024020355

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-28T00:34:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-22
  • City: PICAYUNE
  • State: MS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: MC Tank Transport
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 2301 ET, MC Tank Transport contacted ERTS to report a release of 5 gallons so far out of a 7000 gallon tank of regulated UN3455 Cresols was released impacting asphalt only no storm drains or waterways were reported to be impacted. ERTS dispatched E3 to the site to perform the clean up and tank transfer. E3 arrived on site and with proper hazmat attire advised an estimated 30 gallons were released to a 8ft by 8ft area of asphalt. E3 contained the spill then conducted the tank transfer, once completed the team will work on the asphalt area. The relief tank and damaged tanker were removed from the site with approval from MS DEQ. The impacted area was scraped with shovels, soda ash was applied to the area and then collected it. There was a second asphalt area impacted that was 3ft x 3ft where the driver entered the property this area was cleaned up. three poly drums of impacted solids were generated and will be staged at 3421 Industrial Rd Pascagoula MS until profiled and properly disposed of.

  • City: ELIZABETHTOWN
  • State: KY

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Driver pulled into rack to deliver product. While making turn, the driver caught a piece of angled iron from the rack right at the top of compartment #4 of the trailer. He did no realize what had happened and continued to position truck and trailer for delivery. This movement caused a rip in the inner and outer shell of the trailer allowing product to run out of the trailer. The fire dept. was called and they were able to put down booms immediately upon arrival and contain the product to the concrete apron and the oil/water separator/retention area under the trailer. The NRC was called, KY EPA was contacted along with, a spill response team for remediation and clean up. Lewis personnel responded as well to help coordinate delivery of product still in trailer and make sure clean up was done in timely manner.

item.title: Report I-2023120037
item.description:
Report I-2023120037

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-28T00:34:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-11
  • City: ELIZABETH
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Carteret Disposal Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On Thursday, September 7, 2023, Carteret Disposal received a call from a customer, Lind Line, LLC (from Bill LNU), for the delivery of an additional 30 yard container, to their warehouse. Land Line has an arrangement with DNG Transport that they (Land Line) are in charge of ordering containers for the property. DNG Transport is a repeat customer that routinely orders 30 yard containers for what is historically Type-13 waste. Bill requested that the container be placed adjacent to the CDI container that was already on the property. On Friday, September 8th, CDI delivered the container requested, and placed the container were instructed, which was next to the dock door on the property. On Monday, September 11th, Land Line called for a switch of a container, without specifying exactly which container was to be swapped. That evening, a Roll-Off tractor was dispatched to the Land Line address for the switch. The Driver of our Truck informed me that upon arrival, he viewed two containers, one filled 100% with neatly stacked pallets, and another that was approximately only 75% filled with waste. Based on the past practice with this customer, the Driver instinctively removed the container that was 100% filled. Our records indicate that at 8:46 pm, the container was delivered/dumped at the Waste Management, Inc., Front Street facility. The next day, Tuesday, September 12th, I received a call from a manager at the WMI Front Street facility, who indicated that the load from the night before consisted of flammable hand sanitizer, which was prohibited from being accepted at the facility. This was the first that I or anyone else at CDI was advised or made aware of the actual contents of the, container, as we were led to believe that the contents of the container contained exclusively Type-13

  • Description: On 03/20/2024, at 0712, personnel in the CSXT Lafayette Yard reported CTCX731986, a loaded tank car of Alcohols, N.O.S. (Denatured Fuel Ethanol), leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper Poet Bioprocessing, was contact via PERS (Report #02787. RMS, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found 1 of 6 manway cover bolts less than tool tight. RMS personnel properly secured the manway cover and stopped the release. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative- Sierra Torr (765-712-1696, sierra.torr@poet.com). The car was released for transportation.

  • City: Sedalia

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 60944
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 8, 2024 at 5:36am, an AutoZone tractor trailer had the trailer tires go onto a rain softened shoulder causing the tractor trailer to jack knife and ultimately rollover onto the passenger side of the vehicle. During the rollover, the last pallet on the driver side of the trailer (with an electric pallet jack under it) fell on the last pallet on the passenger side of the trailer that contained 24 automotive batteries. The weight of the pallet and pallet jack cracked the plastic case of 10-12 of the batteries releasing approximately 1.2 gal. of battery acid (sulfuric acid) per battery. The acid did start leaking from the trailer until after the tractor and trailer were uprighted were in the process of returning to the roadway. The plastic wrapped pallet containing the batteries contained the leak until the pallet was returned to the upright position and then the acid began leaking through the pallet. The onsite towing company had a response team come and contain the spill, dispose of the damaged batteries and remediate the affected soil.

item.title: Report X-2024030551
item.description:
Report X-2024030551

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-27T15:12:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-05
  • City: BATON ROUGE
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 18000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 03-05-2024 a CN transportation employee observed liquid running down the side of tank car from the top # UTLX 668009 at the CN Baton Rouge Yard located in Baton Rouge, LA. The employee reported the observation to the Transportation Manager who in turn initiated an emergency response from the CN Dangerous Goods Team. The on duty Dangerous Goods Officer dispatched an emergency response contractor to the yard to investigate. The responding contractor's initial observation found product residue on both sides of the tank car. Further assessment revealed that all (6) manway cover swing bolts were less than tool tight (could turn by hand) with (1) of the swing bolts in the down position causing a leak from the manway cover due to an improper seal of the gasket. The shipper security seal was found to be intact. The shipper manway cover security seal was removed and the cover was opened for the purpose of replacing the gasket. The manway cover swing bolts were then tightened in a star pattern utilizing an 18" pipe wrench. The tank car was then moved to an accessible track for the purpose of exterior cleaning.

item.title: Report X-2024030550
item.description:
Report X-2024030550

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-27T15:12:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-24
  • City: GEISMAR
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 21000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 02-24-2024 a CN transportation employee observed liquid dripping down the side of tank car # UTLX 125078 (Loaded - Spent Sulfuric Acid - UN ID - 1832 - Class 8) while performing switching operations at the CN Geismar Yard located in Geismar, LA. The employee notified the CN Transportation Manager who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team for an emergency response. The responding CN Dangerous Goods Officer performed an inspection of the tank car and noted spillage on the BL side of the car and liquid dripping the eduction line securement flange. Further inspection revealed: (1) of the (4) flange securement fasteners was not properly tightened and could be freely moved by hand. The 1" air valve was in the completely open position with its securement plug securely installed. The 2" liquid eduction line securement cap was less than tool tight (could be turned by hand. The loose liquid eduction line cap was the source of the leak. The tank car's internal pressure was relieved through the 1" air valve stopping the leak. The Liquid eduction line securement cap was properly tightened with an 18" pipe wrench. The 1" air valve was closed, and its securement plug was properly tightened with an 18" pipe wrench. The tank car was then decontaminated by a CN hired contractor. A contractor hired by the responsible party replaced all (4) liquid eduction line flange bolts and securement nuts. The tank car was then pressured up to 10 PSI with a standard air compressor and inspected for leaks. No leaks were discovered.

item.title: Report X-2024030549
item.description:
Report X-2024030549

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-27T15:12:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-22
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Chicago Central and Pacific Railroad
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 20000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 02-22-2024 a CN mechanical performing an inspection observed that the bottom outlet valve appeared to be wet around the valve of tank car # PROX 45654 along with a strong Ethanol type odor in the area. The employee notified the Transportation Manager who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team. The tank car was set out to an isolation track for inspection by a CN emergency response contractor. A CN emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the location for mitigation. Contractor performed an inspection of the tank car and found the bottom outlet valve to be leaking from the threads of the bottom outlet valve cap as a result of the BOV not creating a proper seal and the BOV cap not tight enough to contain the leak. (The BOV cap was found to be less than tool tight and the BOV valve in the closed position and pinned upon initial inspection). HMR did observe cable seals to be correctly in place. The BOV valve handle was cycled several times to the open and closed position to free any debris that may have been trapped in the BOV sealing surface potentially causing the leak. The BOV cap was then removed and observed for 20 minutes to ensure there was no further leakage from the valve. It was noted that the BOV cap gasket was deformed and was replaced. The bottom outlet valve cap was then re-installed and tightened with a 36" pipe wrench. Upon tightening the BOV cap, Contractor proceeded to place new cable seals on the BOV / Cap.

  • Description: Shipment 001-57807886 was tendered by Sky Courier on 2/7. The airway bill commodity section was listed as aircraft part. The driver was asked if there were any batteries and he responded no, just an aircraft part. The security screener x-rayed the piece and saw what looked like batteries. He opened the package and saw that it was batteries for an Emergency locator transmitter ( EL T ). These Lithium Ion aircraft batteries are prohibited for carriage as cargo or COMA T on passenger aircraft.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LAB experienced a UN1789 Blue Whale Muriatic Acid pH Reducer release from a box containing (2) 1-gallon poly jugs. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5-gallons of product released to a 4’ x 8’ area of the trailer floor due to a forklift puncture. Two damaged 1-gallon poly jugs were placed into a 5-gallon poly pail. Twelve impacted but not damaged jugs were placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. Sodium bicarb was then deployed and utilized to neutralize the impacted areas. All impacted neutralized absorbents and cardboard were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

GES personnel completed a tote transfer into one (1) new tote that was staged onsite. The crew deployed absorbents to the release and worked them in utilizing hand tools.   • Description: FULLY LABELED HAZ-MAT IRREG SHIPMENT WAS DISCOVERED DRIPPING LIQUID AND EMITTING A SOLVENT-LIKE ODOR BY THE UNLOAD SUPERVISOR IN SECTION-B DOOR 13 ON THE CATWALK. WITHOUT TOUCHING THE AREA HE EVACUATED THE AREA AND CONTACTED THE DMP. A DESINGNATED RESPONDER ARRIVED WITHIN 2 MINUTES WITH A FULLY STOCKED SPILL CART AND DONNING THE PROPER PPE. THE DAMAGE WAS CONTAINED AND A SMALL 6" RADIUS PUDDLE CLEANED UP, THEN ALL AFFECTED MATERIALS WERE TRANSPORTED TO THE DMP PROCESSING AREA. CLOSER INSPECTION REVEALED A MINISCULE PIN-HEAD SIZE PUNCTURE HOLE AT THE CORNER OF THE BASE OF A 5-GAL POLY, CLOSED HEAD PAIL.

SHE THEN LOOKED UP THE SDS FOR THE PRODUCT LISTED ON THE PACKING SLIP AND NOTICED IT SAID THE ITEM WAS REGULATED FOR TRANSPORTATION. SHE THEN CALLED THE HAZMAT SUPPORT CENTER WHO INSTRUCTED HER TO OPEN THE BOX TO CONFIRM THE CONTENTS. THE CONTENTS WERE CONFIRMED AND THE HAZMAT SUPPORT CENTER SAID THE BOX WAS A SUSPECTED UNDECLARED HAZMAT AND TO GIVE IT TO A DESIGNATED RESPONDER.

  • Description: On March 15, 2024, one (1) 1-gallon pail of UN3149 was punctured by a nail in transit and released approximately one (1) teaspoon of product to a cardboard box. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted site. All impacted materials were collected and containerized into one (1) 5-gallon bucket for disposal purposes. The damaged one-gallon jug was collected and containerized into one (1) additional 5-gallon bucket for disposal purposes. The buckets were properly labeled and possession of the material was taken by RLC to be disposed of through their bulk waste stream.

  • Description: A FULLY LABELED HAZMAT PACKAGE THAT APPEARED TO BE LEAKING WAS DISCOVERED BY AN UNLOADER IN THE TRAILER ON BAY 51. THE UNLOADER LEFT THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR. WITHIN 5 MINUTES A DMP RESPONDER ARRIVED DONNING THE CORRECT PPE AND USING THE APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET, DETERMINED THAT THE PACKAGE COULD BE SAFELY TRANSPORTED BACK TO THE DMP. UPON FURTHER INSPECTION IT WAS REVEALED THAT THE CAP ON ONE OF THE INNER PLASTIC CONTAINERS WAS CRACKED AND LOOSE BY 1/6 OF A TURN, RESULTING IN TWO OUNCES OF LIQUID LEAKING OUT ONTO THE OUTER CARTON. THERE WAS NO PACKING MATERIAL.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-25T15:12:33+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-14
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 14, 2024, two (2) 55-gallon drums of UN3098 were punctured by a forklift and released approximately twenty (20) gallons of product to the trailer floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews utilized duct tape to patch the damaged drums to prevent additional release. TLE crews collected and containerized the damaged drums into two (2) 95-gallon overpack drums for disposal purposes. Soda ash was deployed worked in with hand tools. A granular absorbent and a degreasing agent were deployed and worked in with hand tools. All undamaged cargo was wiped with absorbent pads to remove any residual product and repalletized for continued processing and shipping. All impacted materials were collected and containerized in one (1) 35-gallon drum for disposal purposes. Soda ash was deployed to neutralize the impacted outside the concrete ground and worked in with hand tools. All impacted materials were collected and containerized in one (1) additional 35-gallon drum for disposal purposes.

  • Description: On March 14, 2024, one (1) 20-gallon drum containing hydrogen peroxide was damaged by a load shift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. Crews placed the damaged 20-gallon drum into a 55-gallon drum and set aside for terminal disposal. HES personnel deployed granular absorbents and a neutralizer to the hydrogen peroxide-impacted trailer interior and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for terminal disposal.

  • Description: DURING PACKAGE X-RAY AT THE UPS FACILITY IN THE UNITED KINGDOM, ONE AIR PACKAGE FROM UNITED ARAB EMIRATES TO THE UNITED KINGDOM WAS FOUND TO CONTAIN A DANGEROUS GOOD PRODUCT. THERE IS ONE CAN OF TURBO DOKHA AIR PIPE CLEANER X 150 ML, CONTENTS COMPRESSED GAS LIQUID 99.9% TETRAFLUOROETHANE, CAS NO 811-97-2. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER SHIPPING POLY BAG MAILER. THE PACKAGE WAS FLOWN ON UPS AIRCRAFT PRIOR TO THE DISCOVERY OF THE UNDECLARED CONTENTS. THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM UNITED ARAB EMIRATES USING UPS ACCOUNT 84YY56, SMSA EXPRESS TRANSPORTATION LLC, P.O. BOX 36670, DUBAI, UNITED ARAB EMIRATES.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: The package was sitting on roller in unload when QA noticed the box was wet from the top. Plus it had a strong smell coming from the box. QA immediately got a red tote and transported hazmat to cage to be processed properly. DescribePack: The cap on one of the bottles was loose. Despite the great packing from the shipper the cap still failed to be on tight and the product leaked eating through the box as well as the inner packing. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Placed in red tote making sure nobody else touched the box and placed hazmat in cage to be processed properly.

item.description:

  • City: PALATINE
  • State: IL

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: GOT A LEAKING PACKAGE FROM BAY 23 IN THE NORTHEAST PRIMARY. RESPONDER RETURNED THE LEAKING PACKAGE TO THE DMP. IN THE DMP, OPENED THE BOX TO BEGIN WORKING ON THE LEAKING TO DISCOVER THE PRODUCT WITH A CORROSIVE DIAMOND LABEL ON IT. IMMEDIATELY STOPPED, AND NOTIFIED RMP, WHO IN TURN NOTIFIED THE CHSP. AFTER CALLING THE UNDECLARED HOTLINE, GOT PERMISSION TO PROCESS THE CORROSIVE MATERIAL. THE OUTSIDE CARTON HAD NO HAZMAT INDICATIONS ON IT. THE INTERIOR OF THE CARTON THE HAZMAT WAS IN A CLEAR PLASTIC BAG WITH ANOTHER ITEM, CORROSIVE LIQUIDS, N.O.S. THERE WAS ONLY THREE AIR BAGS OF PACKING MATERIAL IN THE BOX AS WELL.
